feature.name: daily wage calculator
feature.description: The daily wage calculator is a payroll system feature that automatically computes daily pay rates for employees taking unpaid leave by dividing total salary (basic plus allowances) by the actual working days in a month. It deducts public holidays from the working day count to ensure accurate salary reductions. When unpaid leave is approved, the system automatically generates a corresponding pay deduction reflected on the payroll table. The calculator supports both calendar day-based and working day-based leave policies, adapting the calculation method according to organizational policy. This feature ensures consistent and accurate salary deductions for unpaid leave across the payroll system.

source_articles_index.title: How is daily pay calculated
source_articles_index.article_summary: This article explains how daily pay is calculated for unpaid leave deductions. It defines the daily pay formula as total salary (basic + allowance) divided by actual working days in the month. The article clarifies that actual working days are determined by subtracting public holidays from the total working days specified in the organization's leave policy (either calendar days or working days). Upon approval of an unpaid leave request, an automatic pay deduction is created and reflected on the payroll table using the calculated daily pay rate.

source_articles_index.title: Introduction to daily wage calculator
source_articles_index.article_summary: Introduces the Daily Wage Calculator feature as a flexible payroll tool that replaces limited legacy options. Explains three calculation bases (calendar days, working days, custom days), salary component selection options, and the feature's impact on salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deductions. Provides navigation path (Settings → Payroll → Daily Wage Calculation) and clarifies regional labor law compliance, particularly for UAE and KSA.

source_articles_index.title: Salary Proration
source_articles_index.article_summary: This article explains how Super admins can update salary proration settings through the Daily Wage Calculator (DWC) by navigating to Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation and selecting calculation bases (custom days, calendar days, or working days). Changes affect all active unpaid payroll amounts. When payroll month is open with submitted prorated salary transactions, Super admins must reject those transactions before saving new proration settings.

Provide a flexible and customizable method for calculating daily wages to determine salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deduction amounts with greater control and alignment to company policies and regional labor laws.

To adjust and calculate an employee's salary proportionally based on the actual days worked, affecting their first salary and end-of-service settlement by selecting appropriate calculation bases (custom days, calendar days, or working days)

procedures.procedure_name: Calculate Daily Pay for Unpaid Leave Deduction
procedures.when_to_use: When an unpaid leave request has been approved and a salary deduction must be calculated and applied
steps: Receive and approve unpaid leave request
Identify the organization's leave policy (calendar days or working days)
Determine the total number of days in the policy (e.g., 30 calendar days or 22 working days)
Identify all public holidays falling in the month
Subtract public holidays from the total working days to calculate actual working days
Calculate daily pay using formula: Daily Pay = Salary Amount (Basic + Allowance) / Actual Working Days
Automatically generate pay deduction on payroll table based on calculated daily pay and number of unpaid leave days

procedures.when_to_use: When setting up or modifying how daily wages are calculated for payroll processing, leave management, and salary adjustments.
steps: Select the calculation base (calendar days, working days, or custom days)
Choose salary components to include (basic salary, basic salary plus allowances, or allowances only)

procedures.when_to_use: When Super admin needs to change how employee salaries are prorated based on days worked
steps: Navigate to Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation
Select the required calculation basis (custom days, calendar days, or working days)
If payroll month is open with existing prorated salary transactions, reject those transactions before saving new proration settings

rules_limitations_constraints.rule: Daily pay formula is: Salary Amount (Basic + Allowance) / Number of actual working days in the month ; The number of days used in calculation depends on leave policy: either calendar days (e.g., 30 days) or working days (e.g., 22 working days) ; Public holidays falling in the month must be deducted from working days to arrive at actual working days for calculation ; Only the basic salary and allowances are included in the daily pay calculation; other salary components are excluded

Calculation base options are limited to three types: calendar days (all days in the month), working days (excluding weekends and public holidays), or custom days (company-defined, commonly 30 days in UAE and KSA to comply with labor law). ; When using working days calculation base, the system automatically excludes weekends and public holidays as defined in the company's public holiday calendar. ; Salary component selection is limited to three options: basic salary only, basic salary plus allowances, or allowances only. ; The Daily Wage Calculator impacts only three specific payroll areas: salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deduction.

Changes to salary proration settings will affect all active unpaid amounts in the payroll table. When payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions are submitted for one or multiple employees, the Super admin must reject the transactions with prorated salaries before saving new salary proration changes

edge_cases_warnings.edge_case_or_warning: Public holidays must be explicitly subtracted from working days; failure to account for public holidays results in incorrect daily pay calculation. When payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions have been submitted for one or multiple employees, Super admin must manually reject those transactions and then resave the salary proration changes to ensure consistency
